caption: Excellent experience. Magnificent structures and views all around. Locals are really not helpful and give all false information. There are a total of 34 caves among which I felt Cave 16 which is the centre one as soon as we enter and Cave 29 which is a bit far are excellent. For cave 16, If you are fit enough try to climb the hill for the top view. En route to Cave 29, you will get a waterfall and the view is really amazing. Even though this is inside, Cave 29 is huge make sure you don't miss it. It's a holiday on Tuesday(check once before you leave). It will take around 3-4 hours depending on the time you use to take pics. Overall a nice experience. Note: You won't get food inside only water so make sure you get something to eat. Since the overall duration will be more.

Amazing buildings carved from the top to the mountains.  This place has Hindu, Buddha and Jain temple side by side which is a living example of religious harmony existed in India. One of the caves has a 3 story building which will surprise any one who is working in the architecture field. This place has also a nice waterfall which is falling from the top of the building. A nice place to visit with family.

Amazing caves. It was indeed a pleasure visiting this place. Please take the tickets online to avoid the queue. You can avail the taxi inside to visit caves 32, 22 and 27. It was amazing. The waterfall is breathtaking and you can also go below the fall. Each cave has its uniqueness. Kailash temple is an architectural marvel. The top view is amazing. Some of the Caves have multi-stories. You might need one full day to visit all the caves properly. Watch the caves closely so that you can see the mural paintings also in the ceiling and walls. Please check the day, it will be closed all Monday.

This place is simply amazing, we thought we can see all the caves in about 2 hrs but we were truly mistaken, it would take close to 3 and half to completely see all the caves. They also have great garden in the compound where you can sit and relax. The authorities have maintained the cave premises very well... It's a must see place... Truly recommended

Absolutely fantastic, this visit here is the highlight of my stay in India so far, it's really impossible to describe. There isn't very much I can add to the hundreds of reviews already posted, here are some of the 200 photos I took on the day. If you get the chance to see the caves and the kailash temple don't hesitate, just do it, you won't be sorry.

Ellora caves are 3 religious Hindu, Buddhist, Jain's it's surely visitable place children will enjoy üíØ It will take whole day to see all caves Guides are available they will explain the all history and importance of some statues. I enjoyed the place with whole day with family. Thank you

One of the best tourist places of India. Fittingly given the World Heritage tag by UNESCO. Each & every cave enthralls the tourists with its beauty. Cave 16 is the standout among all. Total time to visit all the caves would be around 3 to 4 hours.

Beautiful destination to explore. There are around 34 caves open for people to visit. One of them is kailash temple, carved out of single rock it is an epitome of ancient Indian architecture. It is dedicated to Lord Shiva. There are various sculptures of other Hindu deities also. Some of the caves are also dedicated to Buddhist and Jain deities. One of UNESCO world heritage this place is one of major tourist attractions.

World class tourist place. Recommend to visit during rainy or winter time. Amazing!! Will require a whole day trip if you want to walk through all the caves. Bring drinking water during hot summer walk.

If u love heritage and history, get ready to experience love at first sight! U can only get lost in the imagination of how beautiful these caves might look at those times. Amazing to see how people have built such a huge place 1500-2000 years ago! Do take a guide to understand it properly. Well maintained with security staff at Caves to manage crowds.

Ellora caves have Hindu, Buddhist and Jain caves. Very scenic, beautifully carved and interesting caves with wonderful history. Cave 16 esp is Kailash temple and it is  largest single monolithic rock excavation. Visit to this place made me feel proud to be an Indian. We come from such rich culture. The caves are well maintained. Not the stinky ones. Get a guide if you are really interested in history of caves. We got a guide who had govt ID card. He was an Archeology student and was immensely knowledgeable. This is a must visit place if you're keen to see our history and culture.

This is a nice place to spend a day if you are interested in historical monuments and not only take a picture and job is done. When you enter the Kailash Temple, the first building from the entrance, you will feel how small you are. The skills of our ancestors were mesmerizing.  Do spot the tree... Picture attached....

Wonder. Wonder. Wonder. No words to say about this place. It is one of the largest rock-cut¬†Hindu temple¬†cave complexes in the world, with artwork dating from the period 600‚Äì1000 CE. One must visit this place in their life time

Amazing structures and it‚Äôs an engineering master piece especially cave no 16, the kailasa temple. This is the place where you can see sculptures from Jain, Buddha and Hindu religions at one place. Most of the idols are in damaged state.

We went on this tour with a history legend as guide - Prof. Deglurkar who explained the intricacies and time lines of the sculptures carved out of a mountain over a period of 800-1000 years. One normally tours such sites for fun and not to seek knowledge. The manner in which explanations were provided and the sculptures explained brought alive the fact that ancient India was highly advanced and cultured. Great experience. Must visit .... Just take a good guide to understand the sculptures.

Its enigmatic. Its magnificent. Its stunning.  An unforgettable experience‚Ä¶ Do not visit this place in a hurry. The tickets can be booked online or bought off the counter. There are plenty of resorts and hotels available nearby, so it is very easy to get a place to stay. Just a heads up, the place gets pretty busy during holidays so plan ahead and try to get in early. There is so much history that can be explored here. There are 34 caves so reach early by 9 AM. There's a lot of walking needed, so recommend wearing a good hiking shoes & carry water. I recommend getting a guide for the visit. Hindu & Buddhist caves are together. For the Jain caves you have to take the bus.

Highly highly recommended place. We just loved it. Situated at a distance of about 30 km from Aurangabad, Ellora caves are famous around the world. That is the most famous temple in Ellora - identified by Cave 16. The carvings of this temple are majestic and take your breath away. Each and every inch of this temple has a story to tell.  We were in awe. Just could not get enough of it.  A must visit place !!

Ellora caves , UNESCO world heritage site .  Architecture that will leave you completely awestruck in its mesmerizing beauty . There are 100 caves out of which 34 are open to the public . An architectural marvel where Buddhism, Hinduism and Jainism co-exists in harmony, is a must visit for everyone. UNESCO world heritage site. Well maintained and contains caves from 3 different religions, namely Hinduism, Jainism and Buddhism. The major attraction is Kailasa temple which is a masterpiece of rock-cut architecture.  You can buy tickets online to avoid long queues.

E for Ellora, based on my travelphabet, which  is a UNESCO World Heritage Site located in the Aurangabad, MH. Ellora and Ajanta are the landmark of Aurangabad. This is within the main city, half of day is required to see fully and if u are like me to see minutes and details will take 1 day.  Now maintained by ASI. Ellora is one of the largest rock-cut Hindu temple cave complexes in the world, with artwork dating from the period 600‚Äì1000 CE.  Cave 16 features the largest single monolithic rock excavation in the world, the Kailash temple, a chariot-shaped monument dedicated to the god Shiva. The Kailash temple excavation also features sculptures depicting various Hindu deities as well as relief panels summarizing the two major Hindu epics.  There are over 100 caves at the site, all excavated from the basalt cliffs in the Charanandri Hills, 34 of which are open to public. These consist of 17 Hindu (caves 13‚Äì29), 12 Buddhist (caves 1‚Äì12) and 5 Jain (caves 30‚Äì34) caves, each group representing deities and mythologies prevalent in the 1st millennium CE, as well as monasteries of each respective religion. They were built close to one another and illustrate the religious harmony that existed in ancient India. All of the Ellora monuments were built during the Rashtrakuta dynasty, which constructed part of the Hindu and Buddhist caves, and the Yadava dynasty, which constructed a number of the Jain caves. Funding for the construction of the monuments was provided by royals, traders and the wealthy of the region.  Although the caves served as temples and a rest stop for pilgrims, the site's location on an ancient South Asian trade route also made it an important commercial centre in the Deccan region. It is 29 kilometres (18 miles) north-west of Aurangabad, and about 300 kilometres (190 miles) east-northeast of Mumbai. Today, the Ellora Caves, along with the nearby Ajanta Caves, are a major tourist attraction in the Marathwada region of Maharashtra and a protected monument under the Archaeological Survey of India (ASI).  Derivation of name: Ellora, also called Verul or Elura, is the short form of the ancient name Elloorpuram. The older form of the name has been found in ancient references such as the Baroda inscription of 812 CE which mentions "the greatness of this edifice" and that "this great edifice was built on a hill by Krishnaraja at Elapura, the edifice in the inscription being the Kailasa temple. In the Indian tradition, each cave is named and has a suffix Guha (Sanskrit), Lena or Leni (Marathi), meaning cave.  Chronology : The construction at Ellora has been studied since British colonial rule. However, the overlapping styles between the Buddhist, Hindu and Jain caves has made it difficult to establish agreement concerning the chronology of their construction. The disputes generally concern: one, whether the Buddhist or Hindu caves were carved first and, two, the relative dating of caves within a particular tradition. The broad consensus that has emerged is based on comparing the carving styles at Ellora to other cave temples in the Deccan region that have been dated, textual records of various dynasties, and epigraphical evidence found at various archaeological sites near Ellora and elsewhere in Maharashtra, Madhya Pradesh and Karnataka. Geri Hockfield Malandra and other scholars[who?] have stated that the Ellora caves had three important building periods: an early Hindu period (~550 to 600 CE), a Buddhist phase (~600 to 730 CE) and a later Hindu and Jain phase (~730 to 950 CE).  The earliest caves may have been built during the Traikutakas and Vakataka dynasties, the latter being known for sponsoring the Ajanta caves. However, it is considered likely that some of the earliest caves, such as Cave 29 (Hindu), were built by the Shiva-inspired Kalachuri dynasty, while the Buddhist caves were built by the Chalukya dynasty.

One of the historical place to visit in India. Suggest to extend the visiting hours upto 9pm and having some shows with lightning will make this place more wonderful for tourists across the globe
I must say it is a man made wonder... Most beautiful place i ever saw... Iwas awed by the beauty of this place... However you need a full day for seeing all the caves here ..entry ticket is 40 rs ..

Visiting Ellora Caves is a great experience. Even after the destruction of such good structures, they are still so beautiful. It seems that there is a lot of our Indian history that our textbooks do not tell us.

No one can compare the art of the caves of ellora with any other things in the world. The only monument in the world which is carved or constructed from top to bottom and in one peace of stone and the carvings are awesome..... No words to explain it actually. Kailash temple is the main cave here but all the caves are best. You need a full day to explore all the caves here.

Its a must watch for those who love history and want to see the glimpse of  Ancient India and the art and architecture. Recommend to take a ASI certified guide who can tell you the story or else you will just be looking at the carvings on the stone and some of the stories being told on these stones can only be understood if someone tells it...local guides are not allowed inside the caves so no use spending money.

Ellora caves are the incredible Creation of humankind. It's so mind-blowing and not just one every cave has a lot to showcase. You can easily take bus from aurangabad, it'll take 40-45 mins. The govt. Guide takes Rs. 2200 and there are private guide options also available. It takes several hours to cover the whole 34 caves so visit this early so that you can cover  most of the caves. It should be in your bucket list.

Once you visit the Kailasa Temple (cave 16), everything seems miniscule. The sheer scale of the temple is mesmerizing. The temple would have been painted during its prime and the traces of that are visible in some places. The other caves are also amazing in their own right. Especially the Jain caves, with their intricate carvings.  The inside of the caves are really dark. It would have been better if there were some lighting like in Ajanta.
It's amazing to see 1600 year old temple created from a single rock. These are one of the world's largest monolithic structures and caves.

A place worth going and spending time, few carves are from 8th century and all the caves are combination of Hindu, Jainism and Buddhism One can have a look from 1 no cave to 18 number but If shortage of time than 10-12-14-16 are not to be miss
